title: European Central Bank, Potential Rescuer, Remains Wary
content:
Among its many proposed measures, the eurozone’s agreement on Greece calls for an overhaul of the country’s rickety banking system. The banks' financial condition has deteriorated recently because of controls on movements of money and surging numbers of problem loans.

But on Monday afternoon, despite the tentative accord in Brussels, the European Central Bank kept a tight lid on its emergency lending to Greek banks. The central bank declined to raise a cap on emergency loans from its existing level of 89 billion euros, or nearly $99 billion, a limit that by now the banks may have already reached.

The central bank is evidently waiting for clear signs that political leaders will do everything they promised in Monday's accord. The decision means that Greek banks are not likely to reopen this week, as planned, and could soon run out of cash.

According to the statement issued by eurozone leaders Monday morning in Brussels, a new rescue fund for Greece would include at least €10 billion, and perhaps as much as €25 billion, that would be used to replenish the capital of Greek banks or to shut them down.

The mention of bank “resolution” in the statement — a term meaning to shutter an insolvent lender — was acknowledgment that some banks may be so badly damaged that they cannot survive.

The agreement also calls for the European Central Bank, in its role as the eurozone’s banking supervisor, to conduct a thorough review of Greek banks after the summer. Greece’s four largest banks passed a health check last year, but since then, they have suffered from a decline in the Greek economy and from a drain of deposits by fearful customers.

The escalation of the crisis in Greece in recent months has hit the banks from all sides. Recent restrictions on cash withdrawals and international money transfers have been poisonous to the Greek economy, increasing the number of individuals and businesses falling behind on loan payments. Banks have seen a surge in problem loans.

The government’s financial distress has undercut the value of Greek bonds, which also hurts the banks because they have large holdings of their own government’s debt.

Forced bank closures were another blow. A bank can hardly be expected to make money when its doors are locked.

Bank A.T.M.s have continued to dispense cash, limited to €60 a day per depositor, but analysts expect the money to run out any day, further damaging the Greek economy.

The banks have been closed since June 29 because they ran out of sources of funds to replace the money that depositors have withdrawn. Analysts at Barclays estimate that banks have lost about 25 percent of their total deposits since December, a huge amount for banks that were already struggling.

The European Central Bank could help Greek banks most quickly by increasing the amount of emergency loans they are allowed to draw. But, during a conference call on Monday, the central bank’s Governing Council decided not to lift the current ceiling on such loans.

Before risking any more money on Greece, the members of the council presumably want to be sure that the Greek Parliament will fulfill agreements made during all-night negotiations with the country’s creditors.

Diego Iscaro, senior economist at IHS, a market research firm, said he expected the European Central Bank to give the banks more breathing room if and when the Greek Parliament passed legislation to confirm Greece’s end of the bargain. But restrictions on withdrawals and money transfers are likely to last a long time, he said.

“We estimate that capital controls will have to remain in place for a prolonged period, even if the agreement is ratified by the Greek and other national parliaments,” Mr. Iscaro said in a statement.

title: An Ambivalent, but Hopeful, Mood in Athens
content: Jubilation, almost immediately followed by wariness, filled the streets as Greeks learned of the agreement in Brussels early Monday. Many people were having their midmorning cafe frappé, while others were standing in the ubiquitous bank lines, as the news spread that after a week of agony — a tense referendum, sparring political rallies, bank closings — and a weekend of all-nighters in the Greek Parliament and among the eurozone leaders, a deal to address the country’s debt crisis and keep it in the eurozone had been reached. The mood was ambivalent, but still hopeful. Even some critics of the maverick young prime minister, Alexis Tsipras, now granted him a “Nixon in China” moment, suggesting that having come from the left, he was the right person to reach a deal with an intransigent, fiscally conservative Germany and to dismantle an entrenched Greek system of patronage, tax evasion and bureaucracy. Others said they worried that, despite some compromise, the next few years would prove punishing for ordinary Greeks. Read more... http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/14/world/europe/greeks-welcome-debt-deal-but-reservations-linger.html

title: Both Sides Nearly Walked Out, Financial Times Says
content:
The Financial Times reports that the negotiations very nearly collapsed around dawn, 14 hours into the marathon talks, when both Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece and Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany became fed up and tried to walk out:
As the two leaders made for the door it was Donald Tusk, the president of the European Council, who moved to prevent the fatigue and frustration from triggering a historic rupture for the eurozone. “Sorry, but there is no way you are leaving this room,” the former Polish prime minister said.
The deadlock at that point was over the size and purpose of a privatization fund for Greek government assets, the newspaper said; it took more than an hour of further wrangling to reach a compromise on the issue.

title: News Analysis: Europe’s Deepening Fissures
content: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said about Greece on Sunday that “the most important currency has been lost: that is trust and reliability.” But many Germans think the most important currency that has been lost is the Deutsche mark, the symbol of rectitude and confidence that embodied West Germany’s ascent from the ashes of World War II. That same sense of solidity is badly lacking in the European Union as it confronts the limits of its ambitions, and Monday morning’s painful deal on Greece seems unlikely to restore it. Read more... http://www.nytimes.com/2015/07/14/world/europe/greece-debt-deal.html

title: Grexit, Greferendum, Agreekment. Now, Aggravation.
content: Playing out on social media, particularly on Twitter, the Greek crisis has spurred a whole new vocabulary formed by adding Gr- to an existing word: Grexit, for a Greek exit from the euro; Greferendum, for the Greek referendum. Now, thanks to Donald Tusk, president of the European Council, there is the dubious Agreekment, for the Greek agreement with European leaders on a bailout plan. These neologisms are examples of portmanteau, which Merriam-Webster's online dictionary describes as "a word or morpheme whose form and meaning are derived from a blending of two or more distinct forms (as smog from smoke and fog)." It remains to be seen whether these words have any staying power, but it is certainly fair to say that not everyone is enamored of them. https://twitter.com/thomasfullerNYT/status/620510510522339328 https://twitter.com/PrimlyStable/status/620493499650211840 https://twitter.com/moorehn/status/620543465450012673 I'm with those, undoubtedly including the government in Athens, who are ready to bring this chapter to an end. It's Grexhausting.

content_expanded:
Playing out on social media, particularly on Twitter, the Greek crisis has spurred a whole new vocabulary formed by adding Gr- to an existing word: Grexit, for a Greek exit from the euro; Greferendum, for the Greek referendum. Now, thanks to Donald Tusk, president of the European Council, there is the dubious Agreekment, for the Greek agreement with European leaders on a bailout plan.

These neologisms are examples of portmanteau, which Merriam-Webster’s online dictionary describes as “a word or morpheme whose form and meaning are derived from a blending of two or more distinct forms (as smog from smoke and fog).”

It remains to be seen whether these words have any staying power, but it is certainly fair to say that not everyone is enamored of them.

Bad jokes happen when people exhausted from night-long negotiations write press releases: we have an "agreekment." pic.twitter.com/3z1mk48UL0

— Thomas Fuller (@thomasfullerNYT) July 13, 2015

All this "adding of 'Gr-' to the start of words" business has the effect of making political journalists sound like Scooby Doo.

— Primly Stable (@PrimlyStable) July 13, 2015

Granky RT @TonyFratto: I want all the European crises to end just you can all stop it with the portmanteau.

— Heidi N Moore (@moorehn) July 13, 2015

I’m with those, undoubtedly including the government in Athens, who are ready to bring this chapter to an end. It’s Grexhausting.

title: Varoufakis: ‘We Were Set Up’
content:
In a wide-ranging interview this weekend with the British magazine New Statesman, Yanis Varoufakis, the former Greek finance minister who resigned at the beginning of last week, had strong words to describe what was being asked of Greece.
In an hourlong telephone interview with the New Statesman, he called the creditors’ proposals — those agreed to by the Athens government on Friday night, which now seem somehow generous — “absolutely impossible, totally non-viable and toxic …[they were] the kind of proposals you present to another side when you don’t want an agreement.”
Varoufakis added: “This country must stop extending and pretending, we must stop taking on new loans pretending that we’ve solved the problem, when we haven’t; when we have made our debt even less sustainable on condition of further austerity that even further shrinks the economy; and shifts the burden further onto the have-nots, creating a humanitarian crisis.”
He also attacked the so-called Troika — the International Monetary Fund, the European Central Bank and the European Commission — for their negotiating tactics.
He suggested that Greece’s creditors had a strategy to keep his government busy and hopeful of a compromise, but in reality they were slowly suffering and eventually desperate.
“They would say we need all your data on the fiscal path on which Greek finds itself, all the data on state-owned enterprises. So we spent a lot of time trying to provide them with it and answering questionnaires and having countless meetings.
“So that would be the first phase. The second phase was they’d ask us what we intended to do on VAT. They would then reject our proposal but wouldn’t come up with a proposal of their own. And then, before we would get a chance to agree on VAT, they would shift to another issue, like privatization. They would ask what we want to do about privatization: We put something forward, they would reject it. Then they’d move onto another topic, like pensions, from there to product markets, from there to labor relations. … It was like a cat chasing its own tail.”
His conclusion was succinct. “We were set up.”

title: Deal Hardens Split in Greece’s Governing Syriza Party
content: Word of the deal in Brussels seemed to harden the split in the governing Syriza party of Greece's prime minister, Alexis Tsipras. A blog affiliated with the left faction of his party said the new terms would turn Greece into a "debt colony" and called for Greeks to say no once more. Mr. Tsipras is expected to announce a reshuffle of his government as early as Monday. About 30 members of his party — and two ministers — essentially defected last Friday, either voting no to the terms of a less arduous package or otherwise signaling their lack of support. Mr. Tsipras was able to pass the measures easily because of wide support from other parties. Now, analysts are waiting to see whether he expels those who did not vote yes, and whether he forges a unity government to clinch the majority he will need to quickly pass measures that even his predecessor, the center-right Prime Minister Antonis Samaras, was unable to get through Parliament. One Syriza official, a member of Parliament and also the spokesman for the party on parliamentary issues, Nikos Filis, was on television Monday morning, urging those who had not gone along with Friday's proposals to step down. "If it was me I would vote, register my disagreement and quit," he said. "I would give up my seat." One new centrist party, To Potami, with 17 seats in Parliament, issued a statement saying its members would support the deal. “We are not claiming the role of a government partner," the statement said. "But we are at the disposal of the prime minister toward finding solutions that benefit the nation, both in terms of people and in terms of proposals." Correction: An earlier version of this post misspelled the given name of a Syriza official. He is Nikos Filis, not Niko Filis.

title: Financial Analysts Cast a Skeptical Eye on Deal
content:
[nytmedia id="100000003796234" crop="592" type="image"]

As the sleep-deprived eurozone leaders and journalists stumble home from an all-night negotiating session, analysts are beginning to weigh in on the agreement announced earlier on Monday, and skeptical voices are prominent, suggesting that Europe might have simply delayed a final reckoning yet again.

European leaders have "kicked the ball back to Athens," Jorg Kramer, chief economist at Commerzbank in Frankfurt, wrote in a research note. "Greece has to pass numerous, unexpectedly tough reform laws before negotiations about a third bailout program can start."

It remains to be seen, he added, how Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras of Greece will get his promised overhauls through Parliament not long after he rejected less-painful measures.

Derek Halpenny, European head of global markets research at Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi UFJ in London, noted that the tougher the terms, the harder it would be to restore confidence in the Greek financial sector.

And the fact that Germany proposed a "temporary Grexit" at one point "could be argued as one further step toward that eventual outcome." The deal announced on Monday morning "now appears to have put Grexit risks to bed for a time," Mr. Halpenny wrote, "but not many will say with high confidence" that the issue is closed.

The "doubts and concerns in our view outweigh optimism and euphoria," Carsten Brzeski, chief economist at ING-DiBa in Frankfurt, wrote in a note. "It starts with the fact that there actually is no deal, yet," only "an agreement to start negotiations once certain conditions are met."

The agreement was made possible only by the fact that the Greek people overwhelmingly favor continued membership in the eurozone and the desire of other eurozone leaders to avoid a Greek departure, Mr. Brzeski wrote, not necessarily a sufficient basis for a lasting arrangement.

"To the contrary, the Grexit might have been avoided for a couple of weeks or — in a best-case scenario — for a couple of months," he wrote. "But as in any good horror movie, the ghosts will always return."
